greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Fermat's Last Theorem: a(n) = 1 if x^n + y^n = z^n has a nontrivial solution in integers, otherwise a(n) = 0.
comment: a(n) is the Hankel transform of A000045(n), n>=1 (Fibonacci numbers). See A055879 for the definition of Hankel transform. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jan 23 2007
1, -1, 0, 0, 0, ... is the convolutional inverse of the all-ones sequence. - _Tanya Khovanova_, Jun 29 2007
Also parity of the Euler totient function A000010. - _Omar E. Pol_, Jan 15 2012
a(n-1) gives the row sums of A048994. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, May 09 2017
Decimal expansion of 11/10. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Mar 08 2019

Index entries for characteristic functions
formula: a(n) = (n-1)! mod 2, with n >= 1. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Feb 15 2008
Euler transform of length 2 sequence [1, -1]. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 05 2009
a(n) is multiplicative with a(2) = 1, a(2^e) = 0 if e > 1, a(p^e) = 0^e if p > 2. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 05 2009
G.f.: x + x^2 = x * (1 - x^2) / (1 - x). - _Michael Somos_, Jul 05 2009
xref: INVERT transform gives Fibonacci numbers, A000045.
Convolution inverse of A062157. Dirichlet convolution inverse of A154269.
Cf. A229382, A229383 (near-miss counterexamples to FLT).
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
